metadata.description:
“The land is our food, our culture, our spirit and identity.”

Dear, is a series about indigenous people's magical land and respect for them to raise more recognition & awareness internationally.  
Originally, the "Dear," series started in 2018.

*20 percent of each first sale will be donated to the indigenous organizations,

The Gujaga Foundation  
https://www.gujaga.org.au/ 

La Perouse Local Aboriginal Land Council  
https://www.laperouse.org.au/

Waminda  
https://waminda.org.au/

Sisters Inside  
https://www.sistersinside.com.au/

->  
The runway extends into Botany Bay. Planes landing in Sydney, both domestic and international, use that runway. If you are sitting in a window seat, you will be struck by the beautiful sea colour of Botany Bay. The Muruora-dial clan had lived in such a place for thousands of years, where the strong sunlight pierces the surface of the sea which reflects the colour of the ocean into brilliant turquoise blue to the human eye. Within Kamay ( Botany Bay ), there is an area called La Perouse. It is named after the French navigator 'La Perouse', who stayed there for a total of only six weeks, a week after he arrived in 1788. Ironically, the view of Kamay that you are now seeing from the plane window is the very first location where James Cook and the crew of HMS Endeavour came into contact with the indigenous people of Australia's east coast. And that was only the beginning of the history of western invasions.


ボタニーベイ内に伸びている滑走路。国内でも国外便でもシドニーに着陸する飛行機はその滑走路を使う。もしあなたが窓際の席に座っていたのなら、その綺麗なボタニーベイの海の色に目を奪われるだろう。

強い太陽の光が海に刺さり、海の色は鮮やかなターコイズブルーとなって人の目に映る、そのような場所で何千年も前から暮らしてきた人々がいるた、 Muruora-dial clan だ。

そのボタニーベイ内にラ・ペルーズというエリアがある。その名前は、到着した１週間後、合計でたった６週間しかそこに滞在しなかった、フランス人の航海士’ラ・ペルーズ’から名付けられたものだ。皮肉なことに今あなたが飛行機の窓から見ているそのボタニーベイの景色はまさにジェームズ・クックとHMSエンデバー号の乗組員が、オーストラリア東海岸の先住民と初めて接触した場所である。そしてそれは西欧人による侵略の歴史のほんの始まりに過ぎなかった。

Dimension: 1200 x 798 px
